G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises under Massachusetts law for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 19.proposition: The Boston Municipal Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 1, 19 and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the amount in controversy is within the Court’s jurisdictional limits and the claims arise under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The Boston Municipal Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 1, 19 and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because the amount in controversy is within the Court’s jurisdictional limits and the claims arise under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Municipal Court, Roxbury Division, because the Premises are located in Jamaica Plain, within the territorial jurisdiction of this Division, and the events giving rise to this action occurred there.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Municipal Court, Roxbury Division, because the Premises are located in Jamaica Plain, within the territorial jurisdiction of this Division, and the events giving rise to this action occurred there.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.), including chronic water leaks and conditions that may cause mold or dampness, can amount to a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment when the landlord fails to correct them after notice.

105 C.M.R. 410.500, 410.750.proposition: The State Sanitary Code requires that dwelling units be kept in good repair, in a clean and sanitary condition, and free of chronic dampness and water penetration.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, protecting tenants from serious interferences with the use and enjoyment of the rented premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recognizes an implied covenant/warranty of quiet enjoyment in the landlord‑tenant relationship and applies it in the residential context to protect tenants against substantial interference with the use of their apartments. The court affirms a finding that tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment and treats that deprivation—caused by serious recurring noise—as a breach of the implied covenant, amounting to constructive eviction. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts residential tenancies include an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protecting against serious interferences with use and enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: "He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge… Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment… [show] there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done."

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 776–78 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions affecting health or safety, after notice, can constitute an “indirect” interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the implied warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment is mentioned only procedurally (the judge found a breach but awarded no separate damages). The court does not analyze what constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it address the concept of an "indirect" interference with quiet enjoyment based on failure to correct serious conditions after notice. Its substantive holding concerns the measure of damages for habitability breaches in subsidized housing, not the scope of § 14 liability.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct serious conditions affecting health or safety, after notice, can constitute an “indirect” interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” clause and holds that a landlord is liable where its reckless omission to correct unsanitary flooding conditions, which it had notice of and a duty to prevent, interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. It emphasizes that the 1973 amendment removed the intent requirement and that liability extends at least to reckless conduct, including “indirect” interference, such as permitting repeated flooding to occur. This directly supports the proposition that failure to correct serious health/safety conditions after notice can constitute indirect interference with quiet enjoyment under § 14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In 1973, the statute was rewritten… The requirement of intentional conduct was retained for failure to provide essential services, but deleted from the quiet enjoyment clause; landlords were now liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with tenants’ quiet enjoyment of leased premises. One natural inference from this amendment is that the Legislature meant to abrogate the requirement of specific intent to disturb quiet enjoyment… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 200–01 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.), including chronic water leaks and conditions that may cause mold or dampness, can amount to a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment when the landlord fails to correct them after notice.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses the State Sanitary Code as defining minimum standards of fitness and argues that landlords should have an implied obligation to meet those standards, but it does not address G.L. c. 186, §14 or the doctrine of substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. The text focuses on rent abatement and implied warranty/habitability concepts in relation to code violations, not on whether chronic leaks or mold‑related conditions, after notice and failure to repair, constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus it is not direct authority for the specific quiet enjoyment proposition stated.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation. It… expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units.… I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards…”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 282–83 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.), including chronic water leaks and conditions that may cause mold or dampness, can amount to a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment when the landlord fails to correct them after notice.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it deals with interference caused by criminal drug activity in common areas, not with State Sanitary Code violations, water leaks, mold, or dampness. The court’s quiet enjoyment analysis turns on the landlord’s failure to take measures to remove nontenants engaged in unlawful conduct, not on physical or sanitary defects in the premises. The opinion therefore does not establish that Sanitary Code violations like chronic leaks or mold can amount to substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199–204 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that significant water leaks, chronic dampness, and environmental conditions impacting health and habitability can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case deals with loss of heat and hot water as breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and the timing of rent abatement; it does not analyze or even mention water leaks, chronic dampness, or environmental/health conditions in the context of breach of quiet enjoyment. The opinion is framed entirely in terms of the warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition… We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–62 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was at least negligent, and, in light of his repeated notice of the recurring water intrusion and resulting damage and health concerns, his inaction was willful, knowing, or in reckless disregard of Plaintiff’s rights.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns breach of the implied warranty of habitability, interference with quiet enjoyment, statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and attorney’s fees. It nowhere characterizes the BHA’s conduct as willful, knowing, reckless, or even expressly negligent; it treats the failures to repair as breaches giving rise to contract/statutory remedies, not as a heightened culpability standard. The court’s analysis focuses on the proper measure of damages and the interaction of remedies, not on grading the defendant’s mental state beyond the fact of nonrepair and contempt sanctions.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The BHA does not challenge the judge’s conclusion that its failures to repair the leaky roof and the defective floors were breaches of its implied warranty of habitability or his determination that the leaky roof interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises… Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872\u.proposition: Defendant’s failure to provide a habitable dwelling substantially deprived Plaintiff of the use and enjoyment of her home, in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, and in derogation of the implied warranty of habitability recognized in Massachusetts law.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872\u.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly involves a tenant’s claims for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, based on deplorable, uninhabitable conditions and severe impact on her living situation. However, in the portion provided (pages 872–73) the SJC is focused on emotional distress and the measure of damages under c. 93A and the warranty of habitability; it does not specifically articulate that failure to provide a habitable dwelling ‘substantially deprived’ the tenant of the use and enjoyment of the premises as a § 14 violation. While the facts strongly imply such deprivation, the cited pages do not squarely state the legal proposition in those terms, so the case only indirectly supports it.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 872\u.relevant_excerpt: After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; (2) several basement windows were missing; (3) the apartment windows were in deplorable condition and without screens; (4) ceiling fixtures were missing; (5) the walls and ceilings were cracked and had holes; (6) doors were missing knobs; (7) the flooring in places was hazardous; and (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents.... Gonzalez moved out of the apartment on September 15, 1983.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
